bboxes.raw_text:
Three First National Bank
managers have been named to
Vice President at First National
Bank of Arizona according to
Sherman Hazeltine, Board Chair
man.


They are Glen D. Jones, man
ager of the Park Central office
in Phoenix: Robert F. Clark,
manager of the bank s Flagstaff
office and Joe W. Athn, man
ager of the Prescott office.


Jones of 6737 E. Holly, Scots
dale. Joined First National Bank
in November 1860. His past ex-
perience includes that as man
ager for two branches of the
First National Bank of Nevada and
First State Bank of Gallup, New
Mexico.


Atkins, of Prescott, is a native
of Utah. He had Is years exper-
fence In agricultural credit, was
area supervisor for the US. De-
partment of Agriculture prior to
joining First National Bank in
1859. He Is a member of the
Prescott Kiwanis Club.


Clark, with the bank since lo4l
advanced from bookkeeper and
teller to assistant manager, as
sistant vice presidetn and man
ager. He is a graduate of the
Pacific Coast Banking School at
the University of Washington. He
Is active in many civic actiN-
ties including the Lions Club,
Northern Arizona Symphony
Board, Navajo Army Depot Com
munity Relations and Coo onino
County Fair Commission.

The Mesa Branch of the Mari
copa County Auto License DiW-
sion opened Monday dec. 30)
at 8 am. in new quarters at
1916 w. Fourth St. in the West
wood Plaza Shopping Center,
Fourth Street and Alma School
Road, Mesa.


The old office in the county
building, ll2 w. First ST., was
closed Thursday and Friday dec.
26-27) while county crews trans
ferred furniture and files to the
new location.


County Assessor c. L. Sparky
Sparks, who Is responsible for
county auto license operations,
said the new quarters are needed
to better serve the fast-groWng
eastern portion of the county In
GLIDING the Scottsdale-Tempe-
Mesa metropolitan area.


The Mesa office has processed
Al ,O4o motor vehicle registra-
lions as of Dec. l3, according to
G. c. Bill Norris, chief clerk.
He anticipates the total for the
year to top $4,000. This Is an
increase of IL percent over 1862.


The new office contains 5000
square feet. The first Mesa
branch opened in the county build
ing in February 1858. 1t has
shared the building since with
the Mesa Justice of the Peace
court and offices, Mesa sheriff s
substation and county health and
hospital clinic.


The Scottsdale Sheriff s sub
station will be transferred from
"a E. First ST., Scottsdale, into
the former auto license quarters
in the county building in Mesa
in order to cons olidate eastside
operations with the Mesa sub
station.

Golden State Mutual Life In
surance Company Is headed for
Its healthiest financial year in a
decade, according to the COM
pany s controller, Byron Beverly
FLMI, who bases this sunny fore
cast on the companys year-to-
date financial position through
Nov. 80, 1868.


Barring some unexpected run
of adversities, the company Is
expected to show a net gain from
operations of over $500, 900 at the
end of lo63--a figure not ap-
preached since 1858, the best
previous year on record for the
38-year-old firm.


The company s gross gain from
operations for the first IL months
of 1868 was up by II per cent
over last year. ll-month figure,
Beverly noted, as internal econo-
mics and operational changes
helped accelerate the firm toward
progressively stronger finan-
cial picture"


Premium income through No
vember stood at 500 million,
compared to $6.8 million over
last year, ll-month total, while
gross investment income reached
$l,072,l26 against last years
$oo5, 1926, the company reported.


GMS's assets, which at the end
of 1862 amounted to $20.4 mil
lion, may total more than $22.5
million by the end of 1868. Com
pany resources as of Nov. 80
totaled $22.l million.


Additions to the company s
surplus for the first IL months
of the current year amounted to
$364,lO7, eclipsing last year s
ll-month total Of $20l ,002 by
81 per cent.

NEW YORK A report by lne
referral committee of the build
ing industry maintaining that
criticism of the building indus
try and unions for discrimination
was unjustified was sharply
scored this week by Rev. Rich =
ard Hildebrand, president of the
New York City NAACP branch
and chairman of the joint COM
mittee on Equal Employment OPP
portunity.


Terming the report a COM
pounding of self-serving ration
alizations and half-truths," Rev.
Hildebrand stated, "it Is an OBJ
vous and transparent attempt to
blame the Negro community for
the broad pattern of racial dis
elimination that characterizes
the AFL-CIO building trades un-
ions in this city.


"The so-called report seeks
to blame the victim for his con-
dition," he continued.


The report issued on Dec. lS,
stated that only $40 of 1921
Negro and Puerto Rcan appli-
cants for apprenticeship and
journeyman status in the build
ing trades had met minimum
standards.


The six-man committee was
appointed last summer by Peter
Brennan, president of the New
York Building and Construction
Trades Council, to screen Negro
and Puerto Rican applicants for
apprenticeship and journeyman
status in the unions. During the
summer there were widespread
demonstrations here against un-
ion discrimination.


Mr.. Hildebrand charged that
the report confirmed charges of
the demonstrators that several
building trades unions had no
Negroes.

NEW YORK Eight settings
of prayers in praise of the Lord
will be broadcast over the ABC
Radio Network series, "Negro
College Choirs,'' the first week
in January. The choir of six mem
Der institutions of the United
Negro College Fund will pre-
sent works of composers from the
p8th to the 10th centuries.


The music will be interpreted
by the choirs of St. Augustine
College, Raleigh. NC: FiskUni :
versity. Nashville, Tenn: Wiley
College, Marshall, Tex: as we'll
as Norris Brown College, More
house College, and Clark Col
lege, all in Atlanta, Ga. The pro-
gram will originate in New York
City, Jan. S.


Three other UNCF Choir pro-
grams will be heard during the
month.


The choir of Huston-Tillotson
College in Auxtin, Tex. will be
featured on the broadcast the
week of Jan. IL. Nathaniel G.
Williams Is the conductor.


Under the baton of Robert H.
Jones, the choir of Fisk Uni
versity will be heard the week
of Jan. lo.


The choir of Clark College in
Atlanta, Ga. rounds out the jan
uary series the week of Jan. 20.
]. deKoven Killingsworth Is the
choir s director.

The highest price ever paid
for a painting by living artist
went for a forgery. In 1914,
Hermann Goering paid $462, 900
for Christ and Adulteress" by
the Dutch forger Hans Van Nee
geren who claimed the work was
by Vermeer.

More women than men are
hospitalized In the United States
SO women (for causes other
than maternity and 81 men per
900 population in a year.

There are 3.6 persons per
square mile in Australia lin In
dia, 34o).
